text: So Dave, great to have you here.
Great to be here.
So Dave, who are you?

So Dave Brown, I lead the EC2
organization, that's the Elastic Compute Cloud.

I've been on that team
now for a little over 15 years.

So started out as an Engineer writing code
in the very early days of EC2,
and kind of just stuck around.

And have the privilege
of leading the team,

which is all our compute
and networking services at AWS.

Can I say that
you have been a fantastic partner?
Thank you.
Since I joined AWS.
It’s been a lot of fun to have you on the team.

Loved you spending this proportion of time
following our customers in Telco.
Absolutely.

Especially along the digital
sovereignty.
So Dave, I’ve seen the blog,

what is that AWS is saying in our blog
around digital sovereignty?

Yeah, so we've been looking at digital
sovereignty honestly

in a lot of detail
for about the last three years in earnest.

But I really take our digital sovereignty
story all the way back to 2008.

And so it's been something we've been
focusing on for a long, long time.

In the early days, we maybe didn't
even realize we were doing it.

We were really optimizing
for security and availability.

But those have all become such
critical things

when you start
thinking about digital sovereignty.

So about six months ago, we put out a blog
called Our Digital Sovereignty Pledge,

which really says that AWS
is going to be sovereign by design.
That’s what we’re going for.

We want to make sure that what we bring
from a digital sovereignty and a data

sovereignty
point of view still gives customers

the richness of the cloud,
the functionality of the cloud,

gives them control over their data,
which as I said earlier

isn't far off from what we've been doing
since the very early days of AWS.

But the blog post really outlines
how we are approaching the challenge

and how we're looking to solve it
on behalf of our customers.
Super interesting.

And I found it really insightful having
conversations with you, with our customers.

So should you recap,
which are the key tenets

that we have used shaping our approach
digital sovereignty along the years?
I mean, you have been here since ever.
Yeah.

So which had been the key decisions
that made us sovereign by design?
Yeah, I think

one of the very early decisions
that we took, as I said, was back in 2008.

And at the time people were still trying
to get their head around the cloud.
Is the cloud going to work?

Are we going to be able
to move our data centers to the cloud?
Is that actually going to work for us?

And middle of 2008,
we actually had an event with S3.

And S3 was one of the very early AWS
services.

EC2 was only in our US East one region,
there were no other regions.

And S3 actually had an event,
it was a Sunday afternoon,

I remember it well,
and you can still go read about it today

if you search on the internet
for July, 2008, AWS.

But what happened
is we actually had, S3 used to share

information between three locations,
so Virginia, Seattle, and Dublin.

And when you created a new file in S3
or object in S3, it would actually use
the thing called the Gossip Protocol.

It would actually gossip
between those three locations.

And we had a router on the east
coast of the US

that would just flip a bit
every now and then.

It was a broken router,
we didn't know it was broken.

And over a period of a few hours,
S3 started to tell everybody that the file

didn't exist because this key store that
it was gossiping about became unavailable.

And the way we fixed it as you fix
everything is we turned it off
and back on again.
And that recovered S3 for that day.

But what we were doing at the same
time, was we were trying to design

what the second region for EC2
would look like, and ultimately for AWS.
And that was going to be Dublin.
And prior to that event,

we thought everything was going
to be just one big global cloud,

very similar to what
all of the other cloud providers do today.

A lot of functionality centralized,
and a lot of the other regions
will continue to use that.
And we came into the office on that Monday

and we said,
we have to completely change our strategy.

Because if we are sharing data
between regions, we cannot guarantee

that those regions won't fail
for the same reason at the same time.

And what was amazing about that
decision, is it's meant over

the years we've actually built our regions
to be very, very isolated.

So when we put down a new region,
if we just put a region in Melbourne

a couple of weeks back,
we did Switzerland, we've done this year
in Spain recently as well.

Those regions are complete
AWS footprints of a region.

And so it allows our customers,
or you fast-forward to today,

and from a digital or data sovereignty
point of view, customers

know that the services that they're using
and that the data that they're storing

is always going to be local to that region
and that geography.

And so it aligns very well with what
regulators have been looking for.
Yeah, amazing.
I think these are the key milestones

that you need to go through
while you scale managing complexity.

I think there is one of the reasons
why we said that there is no compression

algorithm to the experience, right?
[Dave] Yes.

[Fabio] You need to clash against the wall
sometimes to listen and understand.

And that's even been true today in how
we think about digital sovereignty, right?

And one of the reasons
we went out with the pledge

and not a solution,
we've seen others come out with solutions,

is they're very hard to come out
with a one solution.

Because we have to look at
how is a country, or a regulator

in the case of Telco maybe,
defining digital sovereignty

and how does that fit with
what AWS has to provide?

What do we have to do to innovate
on behalf of our customer?

What is our customer going to have to do
and how are they going to have to change?

And maybe in some cases, regulators change
as well as they learn about services

on our side like Nitro for example,
and just the level of data protection
that provides.

We've even seen regulators change
some of the strategy

when they really understand
what we do from a security point of view.
So it's a journey.
It's not just checking tick boxes.
But the pledge really says

that AWS is committed to providing digital
sovereignty for our customers.

In an ever-changing world
that's changing faster

than we've ever seen
it change before, we’re committed

to working with our customers, working
with regulators, and bringing our richness

of services
into these regulated environments.

Again, for me,
it was amazing one month ago

when we spent that one week
just traveling Europe.

With you
listening to regulators and customers,
what is that you have learned in this

very intense interaction
that you have had in the last months?

I think the first thing to acknowledge is
digital sovereignty is definitely

something
that is very important to countries

and it's not something that anybody
should be writing off.

There's a very clear reason
as to why they want digital sovereignty

and why they need sovereignty
and digital data sovereignty as a country.

The second thing is I think there’s
still a lot of uncertainty out there

as to exactly what’s going to be required
and how that’s going to work.
And as AWS, we’re

really working very hard to bring
a lot of clarity into these situations.

In many cases
that's happening behind the scenes.

We are working very closely
with regulators.

And again, as I said earlier,
it's really empathizing,
understanding what they’re trying to do,

and then trying to make sure
that the cloud solutions we have solve

the outcome that they're looking for,
but also educate them
in the way that the cloud works.

And so it's very much us innovating,
regulators understanding what we have,

and then ultimately delivering
what the customer needs.

And it's also working closely
with our customers and ISV’s and Telco’s.

In many cases, we have customers
that are owning part of the digital

sovereignty experience
for their end customer as well.

The customers are going to be using
the Telco in a certain country.

And so, together with our technologies
like our regions, our local zones,
even our outposts, all bring certain types

of digital sovereignty solutions
that customers can deploy.
Great to hear.

You know, you mentioned Nitro as a, 
let me say, a moment of innovation where

we are invented the hypervisor technology
essentially having sovereignty in mind.
Yeah.
Can I say that?

Now, should you mention the key
functionality and control functions

that we can provide today to our customers
to be compliant
with the most stringent requirements

in terms of digital sovereignty,
what would you say?

Well, actually
that's another key milestone for us.

I spoke about availability
about regions and isolation earlier.

But Nitro was probably one of, it
has to be the next massive step we took.
At the time, digital

sovereignty, again, we were designing
for security and availability.
We were designing

very much for data separation
to ensure that us as a cloud provider

don't have access to customer data
or can't gain access to customer data.

And so when we initially started off
designing Nitro to really solve

some of the latency problems
we were seeing,

and then when we got to designing
all parts of the system and rethinking how

the hypervisor worked, we started to think
about, well, how do we make sure

that we just have a level of security here
that would never have been achievable
with a software-based hypervisor?

And even first Nitro instance,
the very first Nitro instance

launched in 2012
and the full 100% Nitro instance where

every single part of that machine used
Nitro as its system was launched in 2017.

And today, we’re still the only cloud
provider that has anything like Nitro.
Yeah, that’s amazing.
But from a security point of view, it’s

a very strong separation
between AWS and customer data.

All customer data is encrypted at rest
with a key that exists only
for the lifetime of the instance.
It’s never known to any system.

The other thing is
everything is validated and attested.
So when a machine boots,

we actually make sure
that every single component in that system
is exactly as it should be.

That includes
hardware as well as software and firmware.
Has it been signed correctly?

And if any of that is
found to be incorrect,

we won't actually allow the server
to boot up.

And then the final thing is we actually,
we never built a command prompt,
so there’s no shell, there’s no SSH.

And it was really at the time,
I remember people saying, “Well,

how are we going to run the system
if I can’t log into the system?”

And I think that's a mentality
that certainly other cloud providers

still have is if something goes wrong,
you have to log in and debug or get logs.

And we just said to ourselves, well,
that's not how we're going to operate.

And so we are never going to be able
to access the box.

If we need telemetry,
it's going to be stuff that we can

read off metrics that came off the machine
or sanitized logs
that came off the machine.

All APIs are encrypted and signed as well
and deeply authenticated.

And so from a security point of view,
it really raises the bar on security and

honestly solves a lot of the challenges
that customers have.

Nitro also was the very early stages
that ultimately led us

to graviton memory encryption as well,
which is another hugely important feature
for digital sovereignty.

And it's refreshing, the moment
that we pitch the Nitro value proposition

to our customers, it's a kind of eyes
opening moment for all of them.

So I think this was another key
fundamental milestone.

Where we have taken the right decision
following the right tenet
to be digital sovereignty by design.
Yeah, absolutely.

Now maybe last question.
[Dave] Yeah.

[Fabio] So again, you have spent so much time
with me, with my team.

Yeah? 
[Dave] Yeah.

[Fabio] Talking to Telcos,
Orange, Deutsche Telekom,

Telia, Telenor and I’m for sure
forgetting some of those.

And I have in mind the wonderful example
of Deutsche Telekom T-systems that last

Mobile Congress launched the fully managed
data protection service on AWS.

So the question is, what do you think
could be the role of Telcos
within the digital sovereignty area?
What kind of role?
I think it's an excellent question,

and it's been a lot of fun
working with you and the team.

As you know, I did think you were crazy
when you started.
I probably still do.

But bringing the very early
Telco ideas to me and saying, “How

do we solve these problems?” And
some of those are really hard challenges.

Outposts came out
of some of those early interactions,

and we've really actually driven
a lot of innovation in AWS
through Telco requirements.
And I think that's going to be an area

of just incredible innovation
for us going forward.

And it's really sort of
forced us out of our regions

and into the edge with local zones
and outposts and all this other technology
we’re doing now.

So it's been a lot of fun
working with you.
On the question, though.

I think in many countries,
one of the things we see from regulators

and governments
is that they want a local entity

to be able to stand surety
or to be able to attest.
The other word we use is custodian.

And so Deutsche
Telekom is a great example of that.

And the use case
there was really key management.

And what the regulator wanted
was that a German-based entity

had control of the keys
and that it wasn't AWS managing the keys.

The feature we actually launched for that,
which went public at re:Invent last year,
is called XKMS, which essentially means

that Deutsche Telekom, in this case
with an HSM, can actually manage

the keys, the key material,
all the APIs that we need to use

to be able to get an encrypted block back
to do things like EBS encryption.

Or any part of AWS
that requires encryption is actually going
to a Deutsche Telekom-managed system.
Now, there's nothing...
Deutsche Telekom is a fantastic partner,

but other Telcos could do a similar thing
and implement that.

It’s just a feature that we have where
the key management can be done externally.
I also think that that list, that's

a great example of key management, there’s
going to be a list of other things.

Some of those are going to be common
amongst countries.

Some of those are going to be specific
to certain
geographies and regulatory requirements,

but we look forward
to partnering with Telcos

and have them be a custodian
in these countries

on behalf of AWS for the end customer,
for some of these workloads
where that might be required.
You know what, Dave?

I think I really want to thank you
for the fun that we had
while seeking the truth.
Yeah.

I think the beauty has been just
to ask the wrong and the right questions,

but always challenging each other
and listening to what our customers want and need.

Really,
thank you for the thought leadership

that you brought
in this super difficult area.
I think we are digital sovereign by design.
Yeah, absolutely agreed. Thank you Fabio.
Thank you.
